items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides on Thursday morning (21/10/2021). Areas most at risk are Kilnsea Caravan Park between 05.45 and 08.45, Southfield Farm between 06.00 and 07.45 and Spurn Road between 05.30 and 09:00. Strong winds may also generate windblown spray affecting low lying land near the coast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Thursday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Overtopping waves and spray are expected between 05.30 and 09.15 on Thursday morning, 21/10/21. The areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Kilnsea Village, however strong winds may generate wave and windblown spray affecting exposed coastal areas and roads between these times. Please be careful along exposed footpaths and roads as waves and overtopping spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Thursday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 23:45 and 01:45 tonight, Wednesday 20 October, into the morning of Thursday 21 October. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.77 mAODN at 00:45, Thursday 21 October, which is 0.26m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Northley. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and expect to re-issue this message for the following tide, afternoon of Thursday 21 October.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21 October.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday evening.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Totnes, Ashburton, Buckfastleigh, Dartmouth and Torbay areas. This has meant that the River Dart is now rising and there is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast between 8pm until midnight tonight (Wednesday 20 October). We expect river levels on the River Dart to continue to rise and remain high overnight tonight and flood warnings may be required. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message by Thursday afternoon (21 October) or earlier if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook have fallen through today but remain sensitive to further rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible overnight 20/10/2021, especially in the Lower Stratton area. 
Further heavy, persistent rainfall is forecast overnight tonight with further showers forecast for Thursday. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. However there is the potential for further heavy and persistent rain overnight tonight and the river levels in the Cole and Dorcan Brook may rise again in response to this rain.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible in the Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries.  Catchments are wet, and further heavy rainfall is forecast in the area from 8pm today (Wednesday 20 October) until midnight. Flooding is forecast, to occur overnight and into the early hours of Thursday, affecting low lying land and roads, and areas close to the river. Heavy rainfall will ease into Thursday morning, after which flooding is no longer expected, although there may be standing water for a few days. Please take care, and avoid fast flowing water. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by Thursday afternoon, or if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall this morning. Further heavy rainfall is expected overnight. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 9pm today until 10am tomorrow morning, 21/10/2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon, 21/10/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is still high following rain Wednesday morning. Storm Aurore is forecast to bring further heavy rain until 04:00 Thursday 21/10/2021, which will cause the river to rise again. If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding is possible from 22:00, 20/10/2021. Flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may affect buildings too. The river should begin to fall by 22:00, 21/10/2021, but will be higher than normal until Friday. Peak river levels will be higher than Wednesday, potentially the highest levels for a year. Some roads included in this message may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 21/10/2021.

The Western Rother is still high, following Wednesday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and isolated properties along the Western Rother. At Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth river levels will continue to rise through most of Thursday, peaking at about 19:00 21/10/2021 at Lodsbridge and the early hours of Friday in Fittleworth. Flood water could peak very close to properties in both of these communities. Conditions will now slowly improve through Liss, Sheet, Iping and on the River Lod, where in all locations river levels have already peaked or will soon peak. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

The water level in the Gurnard Luck remains very high. Yesterday (Wednesday 20/10/21) 55mm of rain was recorded in Cowes. This is a very significant amount of rain in a short period of time. High tide at Cowes is expected at 12:18 this afternoon (21/10/21). The river will rise for 2 hours after time of high water (until 14:20) before it will be able to drain with the lowering tide. Properties nearest to the river in Marsh Road will experience garden flooding throughout this period. The water level will be much higher than it was yesterday lunchtime (20/10/21). Over the next few days the weather will be dry. At high tide in the early hours of Friday morning (00:27 on 22/10/21) the river will remain a little elevated, but overall the situation will improve. From tomorrow morning onwards, no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. During times of high tide stated above, please keep away from the river at Gurnard Road Bridge. Water will be deep and fast flowing. This message will be removed by 17:00 on Thursday 21/10/2021.

items.message:
The Cripsey Brook has overnight in response to heavy rain overnight and is expected to be out of banks and flood low lying areas on Thursday 21 October. 
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day flooding low lying land, roads and gardens close to the river around Moreton and Chipping Ongar. 
Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur and cause issues during the Thursday morning rush hour. 
No flooding to properties is currently expected.
Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and follow any local diversion routes.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated this afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high and continues to rise. Yesterday (20/10/21) 55mm of rain was recorded at Knighton. Currently, the river is near the top of the bank in Alverstone. Field flooding is expected along the Yar Valley. Golf Links Road will be flooded and today (21/10/21) minor impact flooding will affect Moreton Common Road. Land around holiday parks in Sandown may flood, as water will struggle to drain to the river. Over the next few days, the weather will be settled and dry. In Alverstone, the river should stabilise around 10:00 this morning (20/10/21), remaining high for several hours, it is unlikely to begin to lower until this afternoon. During this time, it may cause some minor impact flooding to gardens. In Sandown, the river will continue to rise until the early hours of Friday morning (22/10/21). As it peaks, it may be bank full at Sandown Road Bridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Friday 22/10/21.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The forecast is for light rainfall during the day and into this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22nd October.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This is a pre-emptive flood alert as river levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall forecast this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 9pm today, 20/10/2021 until 12pm tomorrow, 21/10/2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon on 21/10/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is still high following rain Wednesday morning. Storm Aurore is forecast to bring further heavy rain until 04:00 Thursday, 21/10/2021, which will cause the river to rise again. If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding is possible from 04:00, 21/10/2021 near Lindfield Bridge on the B2028. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens. From 06:00, 21/10/2021 water will affect roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge and could approach properties near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane. From 08:00, 21/10/2021 flooding could affect Barcombe Mills Road, the Anchor Inn and properties at Barcombe Mills. The river should begin to fall by 22:00, 21/10/2021, but will be higher than normal until Friday. Peak river levels will be higher than Wednesday, potentially the highest levels for a year. Some roads may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 on 21/10/2021.

The River Arun is still high and rising in places following Wednesday's heavy rain. The Arun is now falling in Horsham, but minor flooding will continue to affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and possibly fields behind Arunside and playground of Arunside School. River levels closer to Pulborough are likely to keep slowly rising until approximately 16:00 21/10/2021. As a result, flood water will be very close to isolated riverside properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Lock. Some water could also affect the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: Overtopping waves and spray are expected on Thursday morning (21/10/21) between 04.45 and 05.30, as a result of spring tides. The area most at risk is the New Quay Road area in Whitby, however strong winds may generate wave and windblown spray affecting exposed coastal areas and roads between these times. Please be careful along exposed footpaths and roads as waves and overtopping spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Thursday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are properties along North Promenade in Hornsea. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Thursday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds at Beadnell Harbour Road North and Newbiggin Bay North Promenade.  Consequently, flooding of property and roads is possible between 02:45 and 04:00 tomorrow, 21/10/21.  Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. We do not expect Warkworth gates to be closed. 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water on Wednesday at Teignmouth is at 19:45, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Large wind and wave conditions are not expected, however water levels are expected to be high. Expect tides to be up to 0.29m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Teignmouth on Wednesday at 19:45 is 2.44 mAOD, this is 0.29m above astronomical tide level.

Thursday afternoon's tide at 12:30 on 21/10/2021 will be very similar, but slightly smaller than Wednesday evening's. Tides are higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Northerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.29 m. The total forecast tide is 6.15 metres Chart Datum (3.10 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, wave overtopping will affect the beach front. A small amount of water may pond on nearby land, fields and at Climping Street Car Park and could flow or be directed westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards residential property in Climping Street. Tides on Friday are forecast to be 30cm lower, and with smaller waves so no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We may check the condition of the beach at low tide. Shingle and debris can be moved by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 20:00 on Thursday 21/10/2021.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of a low pressure surge and strong North-Westerly Winds.  
Tides will be at their highest at 07:30 this morning, Thursday 21 October 2021. 
Flooding along coastal areas is possible at this time, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.   
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.85 mAODN. 
The forecast surge height is 0.73 m. The forecast tide level is 4.58 mAOD. 
The forecast wind direction is North-Westerly. 
The forecast wind strength is Force 7.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will provide updates to this information, when required.
This message will be updated at 11:00 today, Thursday 21 October 2021.

River levels remain high at the Hammoon river gauge on the River Stour from the rainfall yesterday.  Low lying land and the tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne will continue to be affected.  

Further heavy rainfall is forecast for this evening and overnight which can cause the river levels to rise rapidly again.  River levels are likely to be at their highest between 04:30 AM until 10:30 AM on the 21/10/21.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.  Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 12:00 AM on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife is still high, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flood impacts will likely continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will give the river a chance to stabilise. From 20:00 21/10/2021 the river should begin to fall through Shripney, Bersted and Aldingbourne. The lowering of water levels will be slow and the Aldingbourne Rife will be higher than normal until next week. River levels through Barnham are falling a lot quicker, and are expected to be near normal by Thursday evening. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk, and we will keep grilles clear through Barnham, including at the Trading Post. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.message: This is a pre-emptive flood alert as river levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall forecast this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 10pm today, 20/10/2021 until 12pm tomorrow, 21/10/2021. We expect flooding to affect Tonbridge playing fields, town centre car parks and low lying land and roads from Tonbridge through Tudeley and East Peckham. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, and Postern Lane in Tonbridge. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon on 21/10/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

By which time, flood water could be very close to properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and at the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please continue to operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.message:

We expect river levels on the Ingrebourne to rise and minor flooding of low lying land, roads and gardens close to the river in the areas of Gaynes Park and Harold Park is possible.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.

The River Ouse is high and rising. More than half a month's rain (55mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. For four hours from 11:15 21/10/2021, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties along Whitfeld Lane and Ivors Lane Hamsey. In Lewes, water could affect Malling Deanery near Willeys Bridge, Railway Lane and the Pells area and gardens of Riverdale. Minor flooding could also affect riverside properties along the Lewes Road between Riverside Farm and St John's Church in Piddinghoe. The peak level Thursday afternoon should be similar to that seen Wednesday evening. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday and Monday. Tides at Newhaven are also forecast to be 20cm lower on Friday. Both these factors mean water levels on the Lower Ouse are not expected to increase significantly over the next few days, with an improving outlook from Friday evening. Some roads may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 21/10/2021

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 14:30 on 21/10/21.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 21/01/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The Combe Haven is still high, following Wednesday's heavy rain. However, river levels in Crowhurst are now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts are likely to continue in Crowhurst through Thursday, affecting fields, rural roads and gardens of properties near the Recreation Ground and also near Springfields. Flood water is also likely to be affecting the Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week, particularly in Bulverhythe. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

Minor flood impacts are still likely to be visible along the River Uck following Wednesday's heavy rain. Standing water will remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads throughout Thursday. However, river levels in Buxted, Uckfield and Isfield are slowly falling and so flood impacts should reduce. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river to largely return to normal by Friday 22/10/2021. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

Please remain aware of your conditions locally and avoid contact with flood waters which may remain.

The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St Johnâ€™s Station remains high, but it is now slowly falling. Yesterday (Wednesday 20/10/21) 60mm of rain fell in Ryde, which is a significant amount. It will take another 6 to 8 hours before the water level in the river returns to normal, some residual flood impacts may remain until then. Over the next few days, the weather should remain fairly dry. As a result, no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm and 03:30am tomorrow morning, Thursday 21st October 2021. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46 mAODN at 1:30am, on Thursday 21st October 2021, which is 0.59m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North West (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October 2021.

items.message: This Flood Warning has been issued as the heavy rain currently being experienced may lead to property flooding overnight. Flooding to property is forecast from 11:45pm, Wednesday 20 October. Flooding is likely in multiple areas along rivers in the area, properties are particularly at risk in the Crayford and Dartford areas including around Greyhound Way and Crayford Way. There is still uncertainty in the forecast and not all areas may be affected. Surface water flooding is also likely throughout this period. Heavy rain will continue during Thursday morning though water levels and flooding should quickly reduce once the rain stops. Standing flood water is likely to remain in places. Please take action to protect yourself and your property if you believe you are at risk, try to avoid contact with flood water in the areas mentioned. We will be closely monitoring the situation and will have staff working to keep rivers in the area clear. This message will be updated by 10am Thursday or sooner if the situation worsens.

Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River.
Further flooding could occur at areas in Higher Frome Vauchurch, Frome Vauchurch, Cruxton, Notton, Frampton, Grimstone, Muckleford, Stratton, Bradford Peverell, Wrackleford, Charminster, Frome Whitfield, Wolfeton, Lower Burton and Cokers Frome from 03:30 AM as river levels are rising rapidly.
Properties close to the river are expected to flood imminently. Take measures to protect yourself and your property.

The Bull River is still very high following Wednesday's heavy rain, but is now slowly falling. Flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, roads and being very close to a small number of properties will continue on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. The Cuckmere River along Mill Lane Hellingly, has already fallen considerably from its peak, which should help flood impacts ease. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will enable the river to continue to fall through Thursday. Impacts should begin to ease from late Thursday afternoon, and should return to more normal flows by Friday afternoon. Some roads are likely to be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

The River Ouse is high and rising. Over half a month's rain (55mm) has been measured at Ardingly in the past 24 hours, nearly half of that from Storm Aurore on Wednesday evening. From 03:30 21/10/2021 flooding will affect properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, as well as fields, rural roads and gardens. A further 5mm of rain is expected before the rain clears eastwards at 03:00 21/10/2021. Thursday, Friday and Saturday are then forecast to remain dry. The river should begin to fall by 09:00 21/10/2021, but might not return to normal until Friday. River levels will peak higher than they have all year. Riverside properties are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them, and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 Thursday 21/10/2021.

items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding of homes and roads is expected into the early hours of Thursday 21 October. Heavy rain falling across the North Devon area has caused the River Torridge to rise rapidly. Flooding of property is imminent
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will flood first.
Install flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring river levels.  We will update this message Thursday afternoon or if the situation changes

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising. Over half a month's rain (45mm) has been measured at Haywards Heath in the past 24 hours, nearly half of that from Storm Aurore. From 05:00 21/10/2021 flooding will affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Water will also affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, as well as there being extensive water in fields. Only a further 5mm of rain is expected before the rain clears eastwards at 03:00 21/10/2021. Thursday, Friday and Saturday are then forecast to remain dry. The river should begin to fall by 20:00 21/10/2021, but is unlikely to return to normal until Saturday. River levels will end up higher than they were at the start of October 2021, and could peak higher than during the whole of 2021 so far. Some roads included in this message may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 Thursday 21/10/2021.

items.description: Bumpstead Brook through Steeple Bumpstead to New England
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to low lying land and riverside areas is likely from now, and into the morning of Thursday 21st October.  River levels are reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to rainfall. Areas most at risk are Smiths Green, Helions Rd, Water Lane, the bottom of Church Street, North Street, Blois Road, the Endway and the Blois Meadows Business Centre in Steeple Bumpstead, and waterside properties in Broad Green.  The forecast is for rain to clear over the next few hours and to stay dry into Thursday.  Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 21st October.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected into the early hours of Thursday 21 October.
Heavy rainfall in the East Devon area has caused the River Axe to rise, and flooding to properties and roads is expected. 
We expect flooding to affect properties and low lying roads around Stoney Bridge and Castle Hill in Axminster.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now and install any flood protections products you may have. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by Thursday afternoon (21 October) or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Clyst from Broadclyst to Clyst St. Mary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding of homes and roads is expected into the early hours of Thursday 21 October. Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area has caused the River Clyst to rise rapidly. Flooding of property is imminent.
Properties and low lying areas around Ashclyst Farm, Burrow Bridge, there is likely to be deep road flooding in the Burrow area, Broadclyst Bridge, Clyston Mill, Dymond's Farm, Sowton Barton and properties and farms between Clyst St. Mary and Topsham including Newcourt Barton and Cotts Farm will flood first.
Install flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring river levels.  We will update this message Thursday afternoon or if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook from Crowhurst and Blindley Heath to Penshurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Warning has been issued following heavy rainfall overnight. We expect flooding to affect properties around Haxted Mill and Haxted Road and properties along the River Eden and Eden Brook around Haxted Mill, Edenbridge and Hever. We also expect properties at Lingfield and Haxted Mill to be affected. Further rainfall is possible over the next hour until 4am on 21/10/2021. No further rainfall is expected after this. We expect river levels to remain high until 10am on 21/10/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners, and are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. If you have any property flood resilience measures, please deploy them now. Please take action to protect yourself and your property if you believe you are at risk, try to avoid contact with flood water in the areas mentioned. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cale at Wincanton, riverside properties
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected this morning on 21/10/2021 between 04:00 AM and 10:00 AM.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Cale, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hopkins Court, Bennetts Field Trading Estate, Whitehall, Moor Lane and part of the A371; Hopkins Court, Bennetts Field Trading Estate, Whitehall, Moor Lane and part of the A372.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so.
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brue and Glastonbury Millstream from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Lovington river gauge as a result of the heavy rainfall earlier tonight. Consequently, flooding of property is forecast from 04:00 today, 21/10/21, and will remain a risk during the morning.  We expect flooding to affect roads in Catsham, Cowbridge and West Lydford and the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare road. Properties on Dyehouse Lane, Glastonbury at risk from the Glastonbury Millstream and overtopping forecast at Baltonsborough.
No further rainfall is forecast but the river will continue to rise until the peak at approximately 07:00 this morning. The river will not reach the levels experienced on the 30/10/20. We are continuing to monitor the situation.
Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Thursday, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) at Thorney and Kingsbury Episcopi
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Chiselborough river gauge as a result of the heavy rainfall yesterday. Consequently, flooding could occur between 04:30 and 07:00 on 21/10/21. Only the most vulnerable low lying properties are at risk of flooding downstream of Gawbridge and fields at Thorney and Kingsbury Episcopi. Peak levels will be similar to the flooding in Nov 2001.
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to rise until approximately 05:00 this morning, Thursday 21/10/21 and we will continue to monitor the situation.
Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Thursday, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Culm (Lower) from Cullompton to Stoke Canon, including Hele
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding of homes and roads is expected this morning (Thursday 21 October). Heavy rain falling across the Devon area has caused the River Culm to rise rapidly. Flooding of property is imminent.
Properties and low lying areas in Hele, Silverton Mills, Rewe, the A396 at Stoke Canon and and roads at Columbjohn and Westcott, will flood first.
Install flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring river levels.  We will update this message Thursday afternoon or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Clyst at Clyst St Mary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding of homes and roads is expected into the early hours of Thursday 21 October. Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area has caused the River Clyst to rise rapidly. Flooding of property is imminent
Low lying properties, roads and land around Clyst St Mary will flood first.
Install flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring river levels and have initiated the procedure to fit the stop logs.  We will update this message Thursday afternoon or if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding of homes and roads is expected into the early hours of Thursday 21 October. Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area has caused the River Clyst to rise rapidly. Flooding of property is imminent.
Low lying properties, roads and land around Clyst Honiton will flood first.
Install flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
We are monitoring river levels. We will update this message Thursday afternoon or if the situation changes.

River levels at the Pen Mill river gauge are continuing to rise as a result of the heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding could occur from 08:00 today, Thursday 21/10/21 and the risk will continue through the day.  We expect flooding to affect Mudford Bridge, Parsonage Farm and properties on Main Street. 
The rainfall has now moved out of the area. We expect river levels to remain high during Thursday but are likely to peak during the morning.
We will continue to closely monitor the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cranleigh Waters near Cranleigh and Shamley Green
items.message: Property flooding is possible. River levels have risen on the Cranleigh Water as a result of a period of sustained rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today (21/10/21) and flooding of properties is possible, especially Cranleigh and Shamley Green. The forecast is for a dry day today and tomorrow, so levels are expected to fall slowly throughout today and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. This message will be updated this evening 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. Over half a month's rain (55mm) was recorded at Ardingly during Wednesday. From 10:00 21/10/2021 the Anchor Inn is expected to flood. Flood water will be extensive through fields, and Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to be covered by water, and potentially impassable. At this stage, internal property flooding at Barcombe Mills is thought less likely. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 18:00 21/10/2021, but will not return to normal flows until the weekend. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021
